0.text: Jane's students become more familiar and endeared to her, and Jane becomes quite popular among them. At night, though, she has troubling nightmares that involve Rochester. Jane continues to pay attention to the relationship between St. John and Rosamond, who often visits the school when she knows St. John will be there. Rosamond asks Jane to draw her portrait, and as she is working on it one day, St. John pays her a visit. He gives her a new book of poetry and looks at the drawing. She offers to draw him a duplicate, and then boldly declares that he ought to marry Rosamond. St. John admits that he loves her and is tempted by her beauty, but he explains that he refuses to allow worldly affection to interfere with his holy duties. The flirtatious, silly, and shallow Rosamond would make a terrible wife for a missionary. Suddenly, St. John notices something on the edge of Jane's paper and tears off a tiny piece--Jane is not certain why. With a peculiar look on his face, he hurries from the room

0.text: The Lilliputian emperor is pleased that Gulliver is friendly and cooperative, so he rewards him with some court diversions. The diversions, however, prove to be quite different than one might expect. It is the Lilliputian court custom that men seeking political office demonstrate their agility in rope dancing, among other things. How long and how skillfully a candidate can dance upon a rope determines his tenure in office. Of the candidates, two are particularly adept: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other diversions include noblemen competing for official favor by crawling under or leaping over a stick, a feat for which they are then rewarded with various colored threads. Gulliver also reviews the Emperor's troops; he stands, legs apart, while the tiny men march through. As a result of Gulliver's cooperation, a pact between Gulliver and the Emperor is agreed on. Gulliver is granted limited freedom on certain conditions. In return for abiding by the conditions, he will receive food sufficient for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the articles in proper form, and the Emperor frees him.

2.text: The King was pleased with Galliver's friendly and helpful nature, and thus invited him to display his entertainment skills at the royal court. However, these entertainments turned out to be more than what he had anticipated. It was a tradition of the royal court that anyone who sought a position in politics had to demonstrate their ability to dance the rope dance as one of many things. The ability to dance for a long time and dance with art would determine the timing of receiving a position in politics, particularly two people excelled in this: Redrassal, Galliver's ally, and Flimnap, the King's financial advisor. Other entertainments included scholars competing for official justice by walking or jumping over a suspended rope. Jumping over a suspended rope was a task that earned many-colored coins. Galliver's entertainments also inspected the King's army. He walked straight ahead, while the little people ran through. The result of Galliver's collaboration with the King was a pact between Galliver and the King. Galliver received limited freedom under certain conditions. In exchange, Galliver received enough food for approximately 1,728 little people. Galliver confirmed in a suitable manner, and the King released him.

There was a tradition at the Grand Palace that anyone seeking a political position had to demonstrate their skill in dancing with a rope as one of many things. The skill in dancing for a long time and dancing with art would determine the time to receive a political position, especially for two people who had this ability at a high level, namely Redrasal, Galleve's supporter, and Flimnab, the former financial advisor to the King. Other entertainments included experts competing for official justice by walking or jumping through ropes that were hung up. Jumping through ropes that were hung up was a job that earned many colors. Galleve's entertainments checked the King's army. He walked straight ahead, while the little children jumped through. Galleve's relationship with the King led to a treaty between Galleve and the King. Galleve was granted limited freedom under certain conditions. In exchange, Galleve received enough food for approximately 1,728 little children. Galleve was confirmed in a suitable manner, and the King released him.

6.text: The king was impressed by Galt's friendly and beneficial behavior and invited him to display his entertainment abilities at the grand palace. However, these entertainments turned out to be more than what the king initially saw. 0.text: This scene opens on a plain in Denmark. Fortinbras, Prince of Norway, marches with his army across Denmark on the way to Poland. Hamlet enters with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern and meets a captain who describes the small and worthless piece of land in Poland young Fortinbras hopes to acquire. Hamlet reflects on the futility of war, bloodshed, and the persistent Poles, who will fight for their worthless land to the bitter end. Rosencrantz and Guildenstern walk ahead, affording Hamlet the opportunity to reflect in solitude. He contrasts his inaction to the aggressive behavior of young Fortinbras, remarking in despair, 'How all occasions do inform against me, / And spur my dull revenge. He is angry at himself for delaying his father's vengeance, especially as he watches nearly twenty thousand men bravely marching to their death for a meaningless piece of land. Hamlet resolves that from now on his 'thoughts  be bloody, or be nothing worth.

2.text: I began in the vast expanse of Denmark, Fortinbras, the Prince of Norway, marched with his army through Denmark to Poland. 0.text: This short scene shifts to the Volscian Senate in Corioli, depicting the Senators engaged in a council of war. They discuss the likely consequences of Romes premature discovery of their preparations for war. Aufidius is irritated by this development and reproaches the First Senator for not keeping the Volscian preparations a closely guarded secret. When the First Senator denies any knowledge of a military leak, Aufidius produces a letter that he had received four days earlier stating that the Romans have raised an army against the Volscians under the leadership of Cominius, Marcius, and Titus Lartius. The letter also states that the Roman citizens are rebelling. To dispel some of Aufidius anger, the Second Senator makes him a general for the battle. Aufidius closes the scene by commenting that if he and Marcius should meet on the battlefield, there is sure to be a fight to death.

0.text: This paper discusses the powers of the states and the federal government to impose taxes on the people. It discusses the notion of concurrent powers and exclusive powers as they relate to taxation. Concurrent powers are those that both the states and federal government share. Exclusive powers are those that only the states or the federal government can exercise. In the case of taxes, the authority of the federal government to levy taxes does not preclude the state governments from doing the same thing since taxation is a concurrent power. The only restriction on the authority of the state governments to levy taxes relates to duties on imports and exports. Congress can levy such taxes, but state governments can only do so with the consent of Congress. Hamilton acknowledges that the concurrent power of taxation could lead to situations in which state governments and the national government impose taxes on the same item, a situation that might be 'inexpedient.' However, Hamilton asserts that the prudence of governments can be relied on to avoid such situations. It is not necessarily a 'direct contradiction of power' for a state government and Congress to impose the same tax.

2.text: This article discusses the power of the state and the central government in collecting taxes from the people. This article discusses the concept of concurrent powers and exclusive powers in the context of tax collection. Concurrent powers are the powers that the state and the central government share together, while exclusive powers are the powers that the state or the central government has the right to use alone. In the case of tax collection, the central government has the power to collect taxes, but it does not prohibit local governments from collecting taxes as well, as tax collection is a concurrent power. One thing that limits the power of local governments to collect taxes is customs tax and export tax. The parliament has the power to collect customs tax, but local governments can collect customs tax only if the parliament has given permission. Damien Hamilton acknowledges that concurrent powers in tax collection may lead to a situation where local governments and the central government collect the same tax, which may be 'inappropriate.' However, Hamilton asserts that the government can avoid this situation. There is no direct conflict between the powers of the parliament and local governments to collect the same tax.

4.text: This article discusses the power of the state and the central government in collecting taxes from citizens. It discusses the concept of shared power and specific power in the context of tax collection. Shared power is the power that the state and the central government have in common, while specific power is the power that the state or the central government has the right to exercise without being related to the state or the central government. In the case of tax collection, the central government has the power to collect taxes, but it does not prohibit local governments from collecting taxes as well, since tax collection is a shared power. One thing that limits the power of local governments to collect taxes is customs tax and export tax. The parliament has the power to collect customs tax, but local governments can collect customs tax when parliament is authorized. Damien Hamilton admits that shared power in tax collection may lead to a situation where local governments and central governments collect the same tax, which may be 'inappropriate.' However, Hamilton argues that governments can avoid this situation. There is no direct conflict with the power of parliament and local governments to collect the same tax.

0.text: Mehevi and the other chiefs seem slightly angry at Tommo after Marnoo leaves. Even Kory-Kory appears to bear him a small grudge. Tommo now has been in the valley for about two months and his leg feels so well that he moves around easily. One day he makes a small 'pop-gun' out of bamboo for a six-year old boy, which shoots items out when one blows on it. The boy is fascinated. Soon after, groups of men and women appear and beg Tommo to make more. He does so, and they all run around like children playing with the guns. Their excitement continues for almost ten days. Tommo stops wearing the shoes that he brought from the ship and he ties them in his bundle near the roof. One day Marheyo suggests interest in them and Tommo gives them to him. Marheyo starts wearing the shoes on a strap around his chest, as a bizarre necklace. The Typees do not work very frequently, but one task with which most women assist is the making of the cloth, or 'tappa. Tappa making involves boiling branches from trees and stretching fibers. The process is described in full

0.text: After the combats of the first day at Ashby, the crowds eagerly await the events of the next day. The excitement reaches a fever pitch when the Disinherited Knight is attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert. With the help of another mysterious character, the Black Knight, who comes to his aid, Ivanhoe overcomes his challengers, emerging the victor once again. After the victory, the Black Knight disappears. Rowena crowns the Disinherited Knight, who is now forced to raise his visor and show his face. He is revealed to all as Ivanhoe, Cedrics son. Severely wounded, he faints at Rowenas feet.

2.text: After the first day's battle at Ashby, the crowd eagerly awaited the events of the next day. The excitement grew even higher when the overlooked Knight was attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert with the help of another powerful character, the Black Knight, who came to assist Ivanhoe. Ivanhoe was able to overcome his challenger and became a winner once again. After Ivanhoe's victory, the Black Knight disappeared. Rowena celebrated the overlooked Knight, who was now forced to remove his mask and reveal his face to everyone. He was revealed to be Ivanhoe, the son of Cedric. After being severely injured, he fainted at Rowena's feet.

4.text:
หลังจากการรบของวันแรกๆ ที่ Ashby ชาวปกติได้รอเหตุการณ์ของวันต่อไปอย่างหวาดกลัว ความตื่นเต้นยิ่งมากขึ้นเมื่อ Knight ที่ถูกเพิกเฉยถูกโจมตีพร้อมกันโดย Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, และ Bois-Guilbert ด้วยความช่วยเหลือของ Knight ที่มีอำนาจมาก Knight สีดำที่มาเพื่อช่วยเหลือ Ivanhoe Ivanhoe สามารถเอาชนะผู้ท้าทายของเขาและชนะอีกครั้ง หลังจากที่ Ivanhoe ชนะ Knight สีดำก็หายไป Rowena จากนั้นเข้าร่วมในการเฉลิมฉลอง Knight ที่ถูกเพิกเฉยที่ตอนนี้ถูกบังคับให้นำหน้ากากออกและเปิดเผยใบหน้าของเขาให้ทุกคนเห็น เขาเปิดเผยตัวเองว่าเป็น Ivanhoe ลูกชายของ Cedric หลังจากที่เขาได้รับบาดเจ็บหนัก เขาตกลงไปอยู่ที่รักเท้าของ Rowena

After the battles of the first days at Ashby the ordinary people awaited the events of the following day in great fear. The excitement increased even more when the ignored Knight was attacked together by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert with the help of the powerful Knight. The Black Knight who came to help Ivanhoe, Ivanhoe was able to overcome his challengers and win again. After Ivanhoe won, the Black Knight disappeared. Rowena then joined in the celebration of the ignored Knight who was now forced to remove his mask and reveal his face to everyone. He revealed himself to be Ivanhoe, the son of Cedric, after he had been severely injured. He fell at the feet of Rowena in love.

6.text: After the battles of the first few days at Ashby, the common folk lived in fear of what was to come, and their excitement grew even more when the ignored Knight was attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert. With the aid of the powerful Knight, the Black Knight who had come to aid Ivanhoe, Ivanhoe was able to defeat his challenger and win once again. After Ivanhoe won, the Black Knight vanished. Rowena then joined in the celebration of the ignored Knight, who was now forced to remove his mask and reveal his face to everyone. He revealed himself to be Ivanhoe, the son of Cedric, after which he fell into the arms of Rowena at her feet.

8.text:
หลังจากการรบในหลายวันแรกที่ Ashby ชาวบ้านมีความหวาดกลัวของสิ่งที่จะเกิดขึ้น และความตื่นเต้นของพวกเขาก็เพิ่มขึ้นเมื่อ Knight ที่ถูกทอดทิ้งถูกโจมตีพร้อมกันโดย Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, และ Bois-Guilbert ด้วยความช่วยเหลือของ Knight ที่มีอำนาจ Knight สีดำที่มาช่วย Ivanhoe นั้น Ivanhoe สามารถเอาชนะผู้ท้าทายของเขาและชนะอีกครั้ง หลังจากที่ Ivanhoe ชนะ Knight สีดำก็หายไป Rowena จึงเข้าร่วมการเฉลิมฉลองของ Knight ที่ถูกทอดทิ้ง ซึ่งตอนนี้ถูกบังคับให้ถอดหน้ากากและเปิดเผยใบหน้าของเขาให้กับทุกคน เขาเปิดเผยตัวเองว่าเป็น Ivanhoe ลูกชายของ Cedric หลังจากนั้นเขาก็หล่นลงไปในอ้อมแขนของ Rowena ที่เท้า

Translated passage:
After several days of battles at Ashby, the villagers were filled with fear of what was to come, and their excitement increased when the abandoned Knight was attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert, with the help of the powerful Black Knight who had come to aid Ivanhoe. With the help of the Black Knight, Ivanhoe was able to defeat his challenger and win again. After Ivanhoe defeated the Black Knight, he disappeared. Rowena then joined the celebration of the abandoned Knight, who was now forced to remove his mask and reveal his face to everyone. He revealed himself to be Ivanhoe, the son of Cedric. After that, he fell into Rowena's arms at her feet.

After several days of fighting at Ashby, the villagers were filled with fear of what was to come, and their excitement grew when the abandoned Knight was attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert, with the assistance of the powerful Black Knight who had aided Ivanhoe. Ivanhoe was able to overcome his challenger and win once again. After Ivanhoe won, the Black Knight disappeared. 13.text: After the three-day battle at Ashby, the people in the village were filled with fear of what was to come, and their excitement grew when the abandoned Knight was attacked along with Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf and Bois-Guilbert. With the help of the highly skilled Black Knight who came to help Ivanhoe overcome the challengers and win again, after Ivanhoe won, the Black Knight disappeared. Rowena then joined in the celebration of the abandoned Knight, but was forced to remove her mask and reveal her face to everyone. He revealed himself to be Ivanhoe, the son of Cedric. After that, he fell into the arms of Rowena at her feet.

16.text: หลังจากการรบ 3 วัน ที่ Ashby ผู้คนในหมู่บ้านเต็มไปด้วยความหวาดกลัวเกี่ยวกับสิ่งที่จะเกิดขึ้นและความตื่นเต้นเพิ่มขึ้นเมื่อ Knight ที่ถูกทิ้งไปถูกโจมตีพร้อมกับ อาเทลสแตน Frant-de-Boeuf และ Bu-Gilbert โดยมี Knight ที่มีความสามารถสูงผู้มาเพื่อช่วย Ivanhoe ต่อสู้กับโจมตีและชนะอีกครั้ง หลังจากที่ Ivanhoe ชนะ Knight ที่มีหน้ากากดำก็หายไป  Rowena จากนั้นเข้าร่วมการเฉลิมฉลองของ Knight ที่ถูกทิ้งไปแต่ถูกบังคับให้ถอดหน้ากากและเปิดเผยใบหน้าของเธอให้ทุกคนเห็น  เขาเปิดเผยตัวเองว่าเป็น Ivanhoe ลูกชายของ Cedric หลังจากนั้นเขาก็ห้อยไปในมือ Rowena ที่ขาเธอ

20.text: หลังจากการรบ 3 วัน ที่แอชบี้ ชาวหมู่บ้านเต็มไปด้วยความกลัวของสิ่งที่จะเกิดขึ้นและความตื่นเต้นเพิ่มขึ้นเมื่อ Knight ที่ถูกทิ้งไปถูกโจมตีพร้อมกับ อาเธลสแตน Frant-de-Boeuf และบู-จิลเบิร์ต  Knight ที่มีความสามารถสูงมาเพื่อช่วย Ivanhoe ป้องกันการโจมตีและชนะอีกครั้ง หลังจากที่ Ivanhoe ชนะ Black Knight ก็หายไป Rowena จากนั้นเข้าร่วมการเฉลิมฉลองของ Knight ที่ถูกทิ้ง แต่ถูกบังคับให้นำหน้ากากออกและเปิดเผยใบหน้าของเธอให้กับทุกคน เขาเปิดเผยว่าเขาเป็น Ivanhoe ลูกชายของ เซดริก หลังจากนั้น เขาก็ถูกจับโดย Rowena

0.text: As Fouquet accompanies D'Artagnan to see the King, a man shoves a piece of paper in his hand. While D'Artagnan is talking with the King, Fouquet reads the letter. In Gourville's handwriting, the letter informs Fouquet that a white horse is ready to bear him to safety. The Fouquet destroys the note. Fouquet goes in to see the King. The King asks after his health. Fouquet makes one last attempt to clear his name and defend himself. A little while into their conversation, it is clear Fouquet needs to go to bed. The King summons D'Artagnan to escort the man. Fouquet refuses, saying that a simple footman would do. Once Fouquet leaves, the King orders that D'Artagnan follow him. He asks D'Artagnan to arrest Fouquet, then orders a bunch of draconian measures like a special carriage to prevent notes being thrown out the window. D'Artagnan admits to the King that he tried to save Fouquet, but says that now he will execute his orders. D'Artagnan leaves the King. As he leaves, he sees a very cheerful Gourville heading to Fouquet's lodgings.

2.text: When Fouquet traveled with Dartagnan, they met the king who was folding a paper for Fouquet. Fouquet read the text while Dartagnan was still talking to the king. The text was a handwritten note by Gourville indicating that a white horse was ready to take Fouquet to a safe place. Fouquet tore up the note. Fouquet met the king, who asked about Fouquet's health. Fouquet tried to explain himself again and protect himself again. During the conversation, Fouquet had to go back to bed. The king called Dartagnan to follow Fouquet. Fouquet said that he did not want Dartagnan to follow him, but only the servant. After Fouquet left, the king called Dartagnan to follow him. He ordered Dartagnan to arrest Fouquet and gave him impossible orders, such as having a special carriage to prevent the text from being thrown out of the window. Dartagnan told the king that he was trying to help Fouquet, but he would follow the king's orders. Dartagnan left the king, and while leaving, he saw Gourville quietly going to meet Fouquet at his lodging.

4.text: When Fogget accompanied the Dartanians, they encountered God, who was about to wrap paper for Fogget. Fogget read the text at that moment, while the Dartanians continued to converse with God. The text was a written message from Gwyll, indicating that a white transport aircraft was ready to take Fogget to a safe location. Fogget received the message. Fogget met God, who inquired about his health. Fogget attempted to explain himself again and protect himself once more. During the conversation, Fogget had to go back to sleep. God called the Dartanians to follow Fogget. Fogget stated that he wanted the Dartanians not to follow him, but only to serve him. After Fogget left, God called the Dartanians to follow him and gave them an unreasonable order, such as a special car to prevent the message from being thrown out the window. The Dartanians told God that he was trying to help Fogget but would follow God's orders. The Dartanians left God and, after he left, he saw Gwyll walking to meet Fogget at his lodging.

6.text: When Fogget traveled with the Dartanians, they found that God was about to collect Fogget's belongings. Fogget read the text that existed at that time, while the Dartanians continued to converse with God. The text was a written message from Gwyll stating that the white transport aircraft was ready to take Fogget to a safe burial pit. Fogget received the message and met with God. God inquired about Fogget's health. Fogget attempted to explain himself again and protect himself once more. During their conversation, Fogget had to go back to sleep. God called the Dartanians to follow Fogget. Fogget said he did not want the Dartanians to follow him, but instead asked them to take care of him. After Fogget left, God called the Dartanians and gave them unjust orders, such as a special stretcher to prevent the message from being thrown out the window. The Dartanians told God that they wanted to help Fogget, but would follow God's orders. The Dartanians left God and after that, God saw Gwyll walking to meet Fogget at the burial pit.

8.text: When Fogget accompanied the Dartanians, they found that the Lord was already collecting Fogget's belongings. Fogget read the message that was available at the time, while the Dartanians continued telling the Lord's story. The message was written by Gwyll, stating that the white transport aircraft was ready to take Fogget to a safe burial site. Fogget received the message and then met the Lord. The Lord asked about Fogget's health. Fogget tried to explain himself again and defend himself again. During the conversation, Fogget had to go back to sleep. The Lord then summoned a Dartanian Disciple to follow Fogget. Fogget said that he did not want the Dartanians to follow him, but he asked them to listen to him according to their understanding. After Fogget left, the Lord summoned a Dartanian Disciple and instructed them to follow orders of questionable morality, such as a special table to prevent the message from being thrown out the window. The Dartanians told the Lord that they wanted to help Fogget, but they would follow the Lord's orders. The Dartanians left the Lord, and after that, the Lord saw Gwyll walking to go meet Fogget at the burial site.

10.text: When Forget went out with Dartanian, they found that the prince had already begun collecting Forget's belongings. Forget read the message that appeared at that time, while Dartanian continued telling the story of the prince. The message was written by Guille, stating that a white transport plane was ready to take Forget to a safe burial site. Forget received the message and went to meet the prince, who asked about Forget's health. Forget tried to explain himself again and protect himself again. During the conversation, Forget had to go back to sleep. The prince then called a student from Dartanian to be by his right side. Forget said that he would not want Dartanian to follow him, but he asked them to listen to him with understanding. After Forget left the location, the prince called a student from Dartanian and told them to follow his orders, which were suitable and unsuitable, such as a special schedule to prevent the message from being left out of the window. Dartanian told the prince that they wanted to help Forget, but they would follow the prince's orders. Dartanian left the location, and after that, the prince saw Guille walking to meet Forget at the burial site.

13.text: When Forget left with Dartanian, they found that the Prince had already started collecting Forget's belongings. Forget read the message that appeared at that moment, while Dartanian was telling the story of the Prince. The message was Guille's handwritten note that a white transport plane was ready to take Forget to a safe burial site. Forget received the message and went to the Prince to ask how he felt. Forget tried to explain himself again and protect himself again during the conversation. At that time, Forget had to go back to sleep the Prince, then called Dartanian's students to sit beside him. Forget said that he wanted Dartanian not to follow, but he asked them to listen to him with understanding. After Forget left the designated area, the Prince called Dartanian's students and told them to follow his orders, which included both suitable and unsuitable orders, such as setting a time to prevent the message from appearing on the screen. 0.text: Determined to fight off her depression, Eustacia decides to go to a 'gipsying,' or dance, in East Egdon. Envious of the young people dancing, and later, surprised by Wildeve's presence there, she consents to dance with her former lover and enjoys it more than she can understand. Allowing Wildeve to walk part way home with her, she encounters Clym and Venn, though Wildeve leaves her before Clym can see him. Sure he has seen Wildeve with Eustacia, Venn hurries to the inn and learns from questioning Thomasin that it was her husband. Thereupon, Venn keeps watch on Clym's house and on several occasions frustrates Wildeve's loitering outside the house and trying to communicate with Eustacia. Venn also calls on Mrs. Yeobright, urging her to establish relations with both Clym and Thomasin for the good of all. She decides to forgive Clym and call on him. At the same time, Clym tells Eustacia he must do something to improve relations with his mother.

0.text: Chapter 33 jumps backwards in time a bit. Cathy and Hareton grow closer, though the sight of it annoys both Joseph and Heathcliff. Together they plant a garden, but dig up Joseph's plants to do it. When Heathcliff scolds them for touching the property, Cathy stands up for herself, saying, 'You shouldn't grudge a few yards of earth for me to ornament when you have taken all my land!' . She also accuses Heathcliff of robbing Hareton of his land and money. Heathcliff storms out. He returns later to find Hareton and Cathy reading together. Unexpectedly, Heathcliff does not fly into a rage. Instead he confesses to Nelly that he has lost interest in revenge. 'hen everything is ready, and in my power, I find the will to lift a slate off either roof has vanished!' . Heathcliff continues to be struck by Hareton's resemblance to Catherine. But then, everything reminds him of Catherine. He tells Nelly that he is a changed man. He no longer has the will to live but yearns for only one thing.

0.text: The Mail On a Friday night in late November of 1775, a mail coach wends its way from London to Dover. The journey proves so treacherous that the three passengers must dismount from the carriage and hike alongside it as it climbs a steep hill. From out of the great mists, a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak to Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react warily, fearing that they have come upon a highwayman or robber. Mr. Lorry, however, recognizes the messenger's voice as that of Jerry Cruncher, the odd-job man at Tellson's, and accepts his message. The note that Jerry passes him reads: 'Wait at Dover for Mam'selle. Lorry instructs Jerry to return to Tellson's with this reply: 'Recalled to Life. Confused and troubled by the 'blazing strange message,' Jerry rides on to deliver it

The passenger was cautious, thinking he might be a thief or a pirate, but Larrabee recognized the voice of the man as being that of Jerry Cranston, a versatile employee of the Tullis Russell Bank, and accepted the message. The message Jerry handed him was 'Wait at Dover for McVich.' Larrabee instructed Jerry to return to the Tullis Russell Bank with the reply 'Ascend.' One of the three walked out of the thick smoke and asked if he wanted to communicate with Grad La Roche from the Tullow Russell Bank or not. The passengers on the Malayan Railway were treated with caution because they thought he might be a thief or a pirate. However, La Roche recognized his voice as that of Jerry Cranston, the manager of the Tullow Russell Bank, and accepted the message. Then, Jerry sent a message, 'Wait at Dover for Mac Vicar.' La Roche replied to Jerry, 'Up,' and Jerry was shocked and terrified because the message was strange and unclear.

10.text: On a Saturday night in November 2561, Malay Railieff traveled from London to Dover. The journey was very difficult, and three people had to get off the train and walk forward because Malay Railieff was afraid of one of the mountains and one of them walked away in the thick fog and asked if he wanted to communicate with Grady La Roche from Tallulah Russell Bank. A passenger on the train was cautious and thought Malay Railieff might be a thief or a robber, but Grady La Roche heard his voice as Jerry Cranston, the manager of Tallulah Russell Bank, and accepted the message. Then Jerry sent a message 'Waiting at Dover for Mac Vicar.' Grady La Roche replied to Jerry saying 'Climb up,' and Jerry was surprised and frightened because the message was strange and unclear.

13.text:
On Saturday night, November 11, 2018, the Malala aid team traveled from London to Dorchester. The journey was extremely difficult, and three people had to get off the train and walk further because the Malala aid team feared that one person would walk into the thick fog and ask to contact Grady La Rochelle from the Russian bank, Tulululah. Passengers on the train were cautious and thought that it might be a slave or a thief, but Grady La Rochelle heard the voice as Jerry Cranston, the manager of the Russian bank Tulululah, and accepted the message.

Then, Jerry sent a message, 'Wait at Dorchester for Maxine Wickett.' Grady La Rochelle replied to Jerry, 'Get on.' Jerry was shocked and scared because the message was strange and unclear.

16.text:
In the evening of Saturday, November 11, 2018, the Malala aid team traveled from London to the town of Dorchester. The journey was extremely difficult, and three people had to get off the train and continue on foot because the Malala aid team thought one of them might walk into the thick fog and contact Grady La Rochelle from the Russian bank Tulululah.

Passengers on the train were cautious and thought they might be prisoners or thieves, but Grady La Rochelle heard the sound and recognized it as the voice of Jerry Cranston, the manager of the Russian bank Tulululah, and accepted the message.

Then Jerry sent a message saying, 'Wait at Dorchester for Maxine Wickett.' Grady La Rochelle replied to Jerry, 'Get on the train.' Jerry was shocked and frightened because the message was strange and unclear.

20.text:
On Saturday, 11 November 2558, in the evening, Malala's support team traveled from London to Dorchester. The journey was extremely difficult, and three people had to get off the train and walk further because Malala's support team thought that person might walk into the thick fog and contact Gedi La Rochelle from Russia's Tula Tula Bank.

Passengers on the train were cautious and thought that person might be a prisoner or a thief, but Gedi La Rochelle heard the voice and knew that the voice was Jerry Cranston, the manager of Russia's Tula Tula Bank. He acknowledged the message.

Then Jerry sent a message saying, 'Wait at Dorchester for Maxine Wickett.' Gedi La Rochelle replied, 'Get on the train.' Jerry was shocked and frightened because the message was strange and unclear.

25.text:
On Saturday, 11 November 2558, in the evening, Malala's support team traveled from London to Dorchester. The journey was extremely difficult, and three people had to get off the vehicle and walk further because Malala's support team thought that someone might walk into the thick fog and contact Julia Okhotina from the Bank Benger station in Russia.

The passengers on the motorcycle were cautious and thought that person might be a prisoner or a killer, but Julia Okhotina heard the voice and knew that the voice was Jerry Cranston, the manager of the Bank Benger station in Russia. He had already received the order.

Then, Jerry sent a message saying, 'Wait at Dorchester until Maxine Waters arrives.' Julia Okhotina responded with, 'Get on the train.' Jerry was shocked and terrified because the message was unclear and strange.

30.text:
On Saturday, 11 November 2558, in the evening, Malala's support team traveled from London to Dorchester. The journey was extremely difficult and three people had to get off the bus and walk on because Malala's support team thought one of them had gone into the thick fog and contacted Julia Axelrod from the Bank of England branch in Russia.

A motorcycle tried to be cautious and thought that person might be a prisoner or a killer but Julia Axelrod heard the voice and knew that the voice was Jerry Cranston, the branch manager of the Bank of England in Russia. He had received the order already.

Then Jerry sent the order saying 'Wait at Dorchester until Maxine Waters arrives' Julia Axelrod replied 'Get on the train' Jerry was shocked and scared because the order was unclear and strange.

40.text:
On Saturday, November 11, 2015, in the evening, Malala's support team traveled from London to Dorchester. The journey was extremely difficult, and three people had to get off the bus and walk because Malala's support team thought that one person was missing in the thick fog and contacted Julia Axelrod from the Russian branch in England.

The bike approached cautiously, thinking that the missing person might be a thief or a murderer, but Julia Axelrod heard a voice and knew that the person was Jerry Cranston, the manager of the Russian branch in England, who had received prior instructions.

After that, Jerry gave an order saying, 'Wait at Dorchester until Massin Watters arrives.' Julia Axelrod responded by saying, 'Get on the train.' Jerry was surprised and frightened because the order was unclear and strange.

50.text:
On Saturday, November 11, 2015, Malala traveled from London to Dorchester with her fans. The journey was very difficult and three people had to get off the bus and walk because they thought one of them had gone missing in the thick fog, so they contacted Julia Augus from the English branch.

The driver drove carefully, thinking that the missing person might be a thief or a murderer, but Julia Augus heard a voice and knew that the missing person was Gerry Cranston, the English branch manager who had been instructed to travel ahead.

After that, Gerry ordered, 'Wait at Dorchester until Malala Waters arrives.' Julia Augus replied, 'Get on the train.' Gerry was shocked and terrified because the order was impossible and strange.

65.text:
On Saturday, November 11, 2015, Malala Yousafzai was preparing for a journey from London to Derby. This journey was extremely difficult, and sometimes they had to get out of the car and walk because they thought someone had gone missing in the thick fog. At that time, Julia Augustine from the English branch was contacted.

The driver was driving carefully, thinking that someone was missing or had died, but Julia Augustine heard a voice and knew that the missing person was Ken Cranstoun, the English branch manager who had been ordered to move forward.

After that, Ken ordered, 'Wait at Derby until Malala Yousafzai arrives.' Julia Augustine replied, 'Get on the train.' Ken was given the order with surprise and fear, because the order was unrelated and strange.

80.text:
On Saturday, November 11, 2016, Malala Yousafzai attempted to travel from London to Derby. The journey was extremely difficult, and at times they had to get out of the car and walk because they believed that some people had gone missing in the thick fog.

Meanwhile, Julia Augusta from the English branch received a phone call. The driver was driving cautiously because he believed that some people had gone missing or died, but Julia Augusta heard voices and knew that the missing people were Ken Creehan, the English branch manager, who had been ordered to continue traveling.

After that, Ken ordered 'Wait at Derby until Malala Yousafzai arrives.' Julia Augusta then went back and said, 'Get on the train.' Ken received the order and was surprised and afraid to receive the order because it was unrelated and strange.

100.text:
On Saturday, November 11, 2017, Malala Yousafzai traveled from London to Derby. The journey was very difficult and sometimes they had to take a bus and walk because they thought they would get lost or die in the thick fog.

Meanwhile, Julia Augustine from the English branch received a phone call from the driver. The driver thought they would get lost or die, but Julia Augustine heard the sound and knew that the missing person was Ken Crehan, the English branch manager who had been ordered to continue traveling.

After that, Ken was given an order, 'Wait at Derby until Malala Yousafzai arrives.' Julia Augustine went back and told him, 'Take the train.' Ken received the order and felt surprised and scared because the order was unrelated and abnormal.

0.text: The Governess and Miles, alone at last, speak cagily about Miles's explorations of the grounds over the past day or so, when he's been left to his own devices. Finally, it's time to get everything out in the open. The Governess insists that she's only there to help Miles and to be with him - and he sees that she wants him to tell her everything. As he prepares to confess, she sees for the first time that he's afraid - of her. Miles nervously tells the Governess that he'll tell her anything, but not just now; he says he has to go see Luke . Before she lets him go, the Governess just asks him one thing: did he take the letter she left in the hall yesterday?

2.text: Once upon a time, Cook and Miles were alone together. They spoke carefully about Miles' exploration in the garden a day or two ago, a time when he had rested seriously and a time when everything would be revealed. Cook confirmed that her intention was to help Miles and be with him alone, and she knew that she wanted him to tell her everything. When he was ready to confess his mistakes, she saw him feel anxious for the first time - she was anxious too. 4.text: ในอดีต คุกและไมล์สเปรียบกับคนเดียวกัน พวกเขาพูดถึงการสำรวจของไมล์สในสวนเมื่อไม่นานมานี้ ซึ่งเป็นเวลาที่เขามีเวลาพักผ่อนดีและพร้อมที่จะแบ่งปันสิ่งอื่น ๆ าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล์สบอกว่าไมล

6.text: ในอดีต คุกและไมล์สเปรียบกับคนเดียวกัน พวกเขาพูดถึงการสำรวจของไมล์สในสวนเมื่อไม่นานมานี้ ซึ่งเป็นเวลาที่เขามีเวลาพักผ่อนดีและพร้อมที่จะแบ่งปันสิ่งอื่น ๆ  คุกยืนยันว่าความตั้งใจของเธอไม่ใช่เพื่อช่วยเหลือไมล์ส แต่เป็นเพื่ออยู่กับเขาอย่างเดียว และเธอรู้ว่าเธอต้องการฟังเขาเล่าให้ฟังทุกอย่าง เมื่อเขาพร้อมที่จะรับโทษ เธอเห็นเขารู้สึกกลัวเป็นครั้งแรก เธอเองก็กลัวเช่นกัน

0.text: Spring arrives, and Gray Beaver finishes the journey. White Fang is one year old, and next to Lip-lip, he is the largest yearling. He continues to have his battles with other dogs. When he fights with Baseek over a piece of shinbone, White Fang rips Baseeks right ear and wounds him on the shoulder. Baseek, old and weak, gives up. In mid-summer, White Fang encounters Kiche, who has now forgotten him and has had a new litter. She hovers protectively around her litter, trying to drive White Fang away. When White Fang is three years old, there is a great famine in the land. Only the strong will survive, for the Indians eat the weaker dogs. The Indians also eat the soft-tanned leather of their moccasins and mittens to fill their stomachs. White Fang escapes into the forest to hunt on his own, at times robbing rabbit snares and at times capturing small game, like squirrels and woodmice. At the end of the famine, White Fang meets Lip-lip, with whom he fights until Lip-lip is killed. He then returns to the village and is received warmly and given plenty of fish.

2.text: When the spring season arrived, Grizzly Bear finished its journey and White Fang turned one year old, and it had been a year since he was separated from his mother. He was the largest after Lip-Lip and still participated in fighting with other dogs in different areas. When he faced Begs-Off because his leg bone broke, White Fang bit Begs-Off's right ear and injured Begs-Off's shoulder. The old and weak Begs-Off surrendered in mid-summer. White Fang met Kiche, who had now forgotten him and had a new dog. She was near her dog, trying to chase White Fang away. When White Fang was three years old, he had a heart in the area. Only strong animals could survive because the Indians ate weak dogs. The Indians ate the soft skin of moose and minks to fill their stomachs. White Fang ran into the forest to hunt alone. Sometimes he robbed some wild animals, sometimes he caught and ate small animals such as forest birds and tree mice. At the end of the heart, White Fang met Lip-Lip, who had provoked a war until Lip-Lip was killed. Then he returned to the village and was warmly welcomed and received several fish.

4.text: When the fruit-bearing season arrived, Gizzly Bear had completed his journey, and White Fang had entered the age of one year, and it had been a year since he had separated from his mother. He was the largest of them all after Lip-lip, and he also participated in fighting with dogs in various areas. When he faced Becks of because his knee bones were broken, White Fang bit Becks of on the right ear and injured Becks of on his shoulder. Becks of was an old and weak woman who surrendered in the middle of the summer. White Fang had the opportunity to meet Cheechi, who had forgotten him and had a new dog. She was close to her dog and tried to chase White Fang away. When White Fang was three years old, he had a heart in the area, but only the strongest animals could survive, because the Indians ate weak dogs, the Indians ate the skin of moose and mountain lions to fill their stomachs. White Fang ran into the forest to hunt alone. Sometimes he would steal certain wild animals, sometimes he would eat and eat small animals such as forest birds and mice in the trees, which was the best. White Fang found Lip-lip, which led to a war until Lip-lip died. Then he went back to the village and was warmly welcomed and received many fish.

6.text: When the fruit season arrived, Gizzly Bear had arrived, and White Fang had entered his first year, and it had been a year since he had been separated from his mother. He was one of the largest of all after Lip-lip, and he also participated in fighting with dogs in various areas. When he had to face Becks of, because his knee bones were broken, White Fang picked up Becks of to the right and hurt Becks of on the shoulder. Becks of was an old and weak man, and he surrendered in the middle of the summer. White Fang got the opportunity to meet Cheechi who had left him and had a new dog. She was close to her dog and tried to chase White Fang away. When White Fang was three years old, he had a territory in the area, but weaker animals could survive because the Indians ate weak dogs. The Indians ate moose and mountain lions' skins to fill their stomachs. White Fang went into the forest to find food alone. Sometimes he would steal wildlife, sometimes he would eat and eat small animals such as forest birds and mice in trees, which was the best. White Fang found Lip-lip, which led to a war until Lip-lip died. Then he returned to the village and was warmly welcomed, and received many fish.

8.text: When the fruit season arrives, Gorillie Beer also comes, and White Fang enters his first year, and it has been a year since he was separated from his mother. He is one of the largest of all, after Lip-Lip, and he joins dog fights in various areas. When he faces Becks because of the broken leg bone, White Fang drives Becks to the right and hurts Becks on the shoulder of Becks. Becks is old and weak, and he surrenders in the middle of the summer. White Fang gets the opportunity to meet Cheechi, whom he and his dog have been separated from. She stands near her children and tries to drive White Fang away. When White Fang is three years old, he has territory in that area, but weak animals can stay because Indian people eat weak dogs. White Fang meets Lip-Lip, which leads to a war until Lip-Lip dies, and then he goes back to the village and receives warm acceptance and many fish.

10.text: When the fruit season arrives, Gorilla Beer also comes, and Vai Fung enters his first year and is away from his mother for a year. He is one of the largest of all. After Lip-Lip, he joins the fight with the dogs in various areas. When he faces Becks, because he fractured his leg, Vai Fung drives Becks to the right and causes Becks' shoulder to be injured. Becks is old and weak, and he lost in the middle of the summer. Vai Fung gets an opportunity to meet Zeta, who is separated from her dogs. She is near her puppies and tries to drive Vai Fung away. At the age of 3, Vai Fung has a territory in that area, but the weak animals can survive because the Indians eat the weak dogs. The Indians eat the skin of horses and cheetahs to fill their stomachs. After Lip-Lip joined in fighting with dogs in various areas, when facing Becks, because he was fighting, Gorilla Beer pushed Becks to the right and injured Becks' shoulder. Becks was old and weak and lost in mid-summer. Gorilla Beer got the opportunity to meet Cece, who separated from her dog. She was close to her child and tried to drive Gorilla Beer away. At the age of 3, Gorilla Beer had a territory in that area, but the weak animal could survive because the Indians ate weak dogs. The Indians ate the skin of horses and wolves to fill their stomachs. 0.text: Cedric is in his home, Rotherwood, impatiently waiting for his servants to come home. He is also displeased that his ward Rowena is late for supper. His thoughts are interrupted by the blast of a horn. Then the gatekeeper announces that Prior Aymer of the Abbey of Jorvaulx, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, and a small party of men are on their way to the royal tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouche and want to lodge at Rotherwood for the night. Cedric does not want to entertain these Normans, but his Saxon pride demands that they be offered hospitality; however, he clings to his dignity by refusing to go out to welcome them. Only when they come to him in his hall does Cedric reluctantly welcome them. Cedric counsels Rowena against appearing before the guests. He does not trust the Knight Templar and does not want anything to interfere with his plans to marry Rowena off to the right gentleman. She, however, is keen to hear the latest news from the Holy Land from the Palmer, since she is in love with Ivanhoe, whom she thinks is still fighting in the Crusades.

Nina traveled from Paris and believed she had inherited her father's legacy. However, Lucy had warned her beforehand that her father was still alive. He was a famous actor who had been imprisoned in the Bastille prison in Paris for 18 years. The French government released him because he was a client of the Cachin bank. Lucy was tasked with verifying his status. She hoped that Nina would take responsibility for caring for her father and helping him to recover his health.

Lucy received this news and was shocked. She was escorted out of the room by a red-haired woman. The red-haired woman forced Lucy out, and a young man with a pleasant scent and a cool breeze helped calm Lucy down.

0.text: Emma is thoroughly pleased with her evening at the Coles, but she is uncertain about the appropriateness of telling Frank about her suspicions about Jane or acknowledging the superiority of Jane's musical abilities. At the Coles' party, Harriet heard that Mr. Martin had dined with the Cox family, and there is a rumor that a Cox daughter would like to marry Mr. Martin. To distract and protect Harriet, Emma accompanies her on a shopping trip. They then decide to pay a visit to the Bates household and run into Frank and Mrs. Weston on their way. The visit seems to have been Frank's idea, but he offers to stay with Emma and send Mrs. Weston to make the visit on her own. Emma sends him along, knowing that he will later come see her at Hartfield, but Miss Bates then comes into the shop to ask Emma to come give her opinion of Jane's new pianoforte. In her rambling, Miss Bates reveals that Mr. Knightley has sent his last apples of the season to Jane, who is particularly fond of them.

0.text: The Prison Door This first chapter contains little in the way of action, instead setting the scene and introducing the first of many symbols that will come to dominate the story. A crowd of somber, dreary-looking people has gathered outside the door of a prison in seventeenth-century Boston. The building's heavy oak door is studded with iron spikes, and the prison appears to have been constructed to hold dangerous criminals. No matter how optimistic the founders of new colonies may be, the narrator tells us, they invariably provide for a prison and a cemetery almost immediately. This is true of the citizens of Boston, who built their prison some twenty years earlier. The one incongruity in the otherwise drab scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison door. Tom used to be the stable boy at the Whites' house, but because he is rather dreamy and irresponsible, he lost that position. Now, he does odd jobs and is quite happy. His grandmother comes regularly to clean his rented rooms, and he has a rather oddly disciplined approach to life experiences. He wants to do things, but he chooses specific experiences and then goes out and intentionally lives them. For example, having fallen in love with Helen White, he limits what he allows himself to think about her. One night, he decides he ought to try drinking to see what it feels like. He buys a bottle of whiskey and walks about a mile north of town, where he sits on a bank of grass and gets drunk. In his drunkenness, he goes and talks to George Willard about Helen. George is upset at first, but then they cement a bond between them. Tom decides that, now that he has been drunk, he will not need to try it again.

0.text: We begin with a prologue. An actor dressed in armor comes out on stage and welcomes us to ancient Troy, where the Greeks and Trojans have been going at it on the Trojan battlefields for the last...get this...7 years. Since we're starting out 'in the middle' of all the action, the Prologue quickly catches us up to speed. You know, just in case we've never heard of a little old thing called the Trojan War. Here are the deets: the Greeks have sailed across the 'Athenian Bay' to 'ransack' Troy because a Trojan Prince named Paris stole Helen from the Greek King Menelaus and has been sleeping with her ever since. Simple as that. Next, the Prologue warns us that we might not like the play because nothing good ever really happens in times of 'war.' By the way, Shmooperinos, the Prologue says absolutely NOTHING about Troilus and Cressida, the two characters Shakespeare named this play after. What's up with that?

2.text: The story begins with an opening scene. We see the actors dressed as Trojans ascending onto the stage and welcoming us to Troy. Greeks and Trojans face off on the battlefield of Troy... for a long time, 7 years. Since we are starting in the 'middle' of the action, the opening scene quickly reveals the truth to us. Do you know that if we never heard the small stories about the Trojan War, we would have the following details: Greek soldiers sailed through the 'Aegean Sea' to 'Troy' to 'plunder' Troy because Prince Paris of Troy stole Helen from King Menelaus of Greece and kept her for a long time. It's a simple story. The opening scene warns us that we might not like this because there are no good stories about 'war' on the sidelines. The opening scene tells us that there are no stories about Troilus and Chryseis, the two characters created by the Greeks. Why is it like that?

0.text: Hamilton defends the treaty-making procedures outlined in the Constitution. He responds to the criticism that the Constitution wrongly mixes the legislative and executive branches of government by affording both a role in making and approving treaties. Hamilton argues that act of treaty-making does not fit neatly into the typical purview of either the executive or legislative branch. Therefore, affording a role to both is appropriate. Other critics claimed that the power to make treaties should be limited to the president. Hamilton responds that, unlike European monarchs, the president is only in office for a limited period of time. He may therefore be tempted to sign a treaty detrimental to the nation but beneficial to his private interests since he will eventually return to being a private citizen . It is therefore necessary that his power be held in check by the legislature. Others asserted that the Congress should have even greater authority over treaty making. However, Hamilton responds that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies to the process and weaken the American negotiating position.

2.text:
Hamilton defends the argument regarding the treaty-making process as stipulated in the Constitution. He counters the criticism that the Constitution erred in combining the executive and legislative powers of the state in a single entity by assigning both roles in the making and ratification of treaties. Hamilton argues that the treaty-making process does not conform to the normal jurisdictions of either the executive or legislative branches, and therefore it is suitable to assign both roles.

Other critics are concerned that the power to make treaties should be limited to the President. Hamilton argues that unlike European monarchs, the President will be in office for a short period, and therefore may be inclined to sign treaties that are detrimental to the country but beneficial to his personal interests, as he will eventually become a private citizen. Hence, it is necessary to control his power with the Congress.

Other critics are concerned that Congress should have more power to make treaties, but Hamilton argues that this will lead to delays and unwillingness to act, and will damage the position of the American negotiator.

Other critics were concerned that the power to make treaties should be limited to the president alone. Hamilton argued that, unlike European monarchs, the president would have a shorter tenure in office, and thus might have a need to sign treaties that were beneficial to his personal interests but detrimental to the country. Eventually, he would become a private citizen, and therefore it was necessary to control his power through Congress.

Other critics were concerned that Congress should be given additional authority to make treaties, but Hamilton argued that this would lead to delays and indecision in action, and would undermine the position of American negotiators.

0.text: A French Lord holds a showcase Extravaganza where all the important aristocrats attend. The host snubs the Marquis St. Evremonde and he leaves the reception angrily, ordering his driver to race through the Paris streets. He accidentally runs over a child whose father is Gaspard. He tosses the grief-stricken father a coin and Defarge emerges from the crowd to comfort Gaspard. He throws the coin back into the carriage as it speeds away. The Marquis travels to his country estate where he stops at the village he owns, near his home. A road mender claims he saw a man riding underneath the carriage, who, when it stopped, ran away. The Marquis tells Gabelle, the town official, to be on the lookout for the mystery man. The Marquis travels on to his chateau hoping to meet his nephew M. Charles who is traveling from England.

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

While Cunegonde fights off her attacker, a captain comes in and, enraged at the officer's disrespect, kills him. He then takes Cunegonde as a prisoner of war. The captain keeps Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sells her to a Jewish businessman. The businessman shares her services with the same Inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and flogging of Candide. Cunegonde wards off the sexual advances of both men. Cunegonde attends the post-earthquake execution and recognizes Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. Back in the present, Candide and Cunegonde eat dinner together and hang out until one of her owners, the businessman Don Issachar, comes to get her.

0.text: Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, followed by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. Sir John orders Bardolph to replenish his supply of sack and to tell Peto to meet him at the town's end. He dislikes the idea of marching his men through the town in their rags and tatters. Abjectly impoverished, not one of them could pay him, as so many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye hath seen such scarecrows' . Prince Hal and Westmoreland meet him on the road and comment on the poor creatures whom Falstaff leads. The knight remains undisturbed and is philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, for that matter, the prince seems amused rather than indignant. All are to make haste, says Hal, for Percy is already in the field.

0.text: Now that he has felt the pain of losing his son, Siddhartha has more sympathy with the needs and desires of ordinary people. He again decides to seek his son in the town, but stops when he thinks he hears a special message from the river. He remembers when he rebelled against his own father, and realizes that his father must have suffered the same pain as he, Siddhartha, suffers now. Sorrows repeat themselves. Still suffering, he returns to the hut and tells Vasudeva of his troubles. Vasudeva, in his silent attentiveness, seems to Siddhartha like a god. They both go and sit by the river bank. Siddhartha practices his technique of listening to the river and realizes the unity of all life amidst all its diverse elements. He realizes that in the unity is perfection. His pain disappears as his Self merges with the unity. From that moment on, Siddhartha no longer fights against his destiny. He accepts everything. Vasudeva, now that he has seen his friend attain enlightenment, announces that he is leaving. He is going to live in the woods and be in the unity of all things.

2.text:
Now that he feels the pain of sacrificing his son, Sittart has gained a deeper understanding of the needs and desires of ordinary people. He has decided to visit his son in the city again, but stopped somewhere when he thought he heard a special message from the river. He remembered that when he rejected his father, he understood that his father must have felt the same pain he was feeling at the moment. The pain will keep recurring; he still hurts and goes back to the hut and tells Vasya that he has a problem he doesn't understand. He tells Vasya that he has a problem he doesn't understand.

Vasya, like God in the stillness of the heart, sits beside him by the green river. Sittart practices the technique of listening to the river and understands the oneness of life with its many components. He understands that in oneness, there is completeness; his pain will disappear when he creates oneness with his heart. He does not try to fight fate in any way; he has received life as a whole.

Vasya. Now that he feels his friend awakening to awareness, he announces that he will go into the rain and be in the oneness of everything.

0.text: There is much speculation at the training college when Sue does not return that evening at prayer time. Everyone wonders about the young man she has gone out with, and some of them are convinced that Jude is only posing as her cousin. The situation takes a serious turn because a similar incident occurred the year before: a young man had managed to seduce a student of the same college, maintaining that he was her cousin. The mistress inquires about the two photographs on Sue's dressing table. One is of Mr. Phillotson, and the other is of an unknown undergraduate. The next morning, when Sue does return, she is punished and kept in solitary confinement. The other students feel the punishment is too harsh and prepare to protest. In the evening it is discovered that Sue has escaped from a back window. She turns up at Jude's place. She is soaked and shivering with cold. Jude immediately takes her in and offers her some dry clothes and brandy. Sue is so tired that she falls asleep while relating her story.

0.text: The setting is the heath. A blinded Gloucester is led by an elderly man, one of his tenants. The ailing earl laments that he treated Edgar badly and wishes for the opportunity to once again touch his son, since he can no longer see him. Gloucester hears Edgar's voice and remembers Poor Tom from the night of the storm. In an act of humanity, Gloucester sends his tenant for some clothing so that the Bedlam beggar might be covered. Gloucester is concerned that the Old Man might suffer for having given assistance, so he dismisses him and asks Tom to be his guide to Dover, where he seeks the highest cliff. Tom agrees to take Gloucester to the cliff.

He asks her to open his trunk and remove, his will as he had made two. He wants her to destroy one of them Mary refuses to do anything, which will make her an object of suspicion. She insists he should call in all those present as witness, or wait till morning for his lawyer. Featherstone tries to bribe her with cash. She rejects it, she tries to soothe him but he is too angry and frustrated. Finally, he subsides. A little later, Mary looks at him and realizes he is dead.

He asked her to open his box and take out two documents of his ownership. He wanted her to destroy one of the documents. Mary refused to do anything that would make her suspicious. She asked him to call the person present as a witness or wait until morning for his lawyer, Phoebe Stone. Fred tried to bribe her with money. She refused. He tried to help him, but he changed direction in another way, and soon after, Mary looked at him and knew that he had passed away.

0.text: The Islet David finds himself on a small islet, cut off from the mainland by a small river. He tries to cross the river, but finds it is too wide and deep. He returns to the shore to get his piece of wood, planning to try and float across, but the yard has floated back out to sea. David is now miserable. He begins eating raw shellfish. Sometimes he manages to keep them down, and other times they make him extremely sick. He is especially depressed because he can see a church and several houses on the mainland, but he knows he cannot cross the river. The next day he sees, to his surprise, a red deer, which he realizes must have swum the river. He also discovers that he has lost all his money after the shipwreck. He sees some fisherman, and wildly hails them from the shore. But, to his shock, they only point and laugh at him. The fishermen return later and, in broken English, reveal to him that the river gets very low at low tide. To his surprise and embarrassment, he finds he can practically hop across the river at low tide

2.text:
David found himself on a small island that was separated from the mainland by a small river. He tried to cross the river, but found it was too wide and deep. He went back to the beach to look for wood to try and cross, but his boat had drifted out to sea. David felt uneasy now. He started eating fresh shrimp and mussels. Sometimes he could catch them, but sometimes it made him feel very sick. He felt uneasy because he saw several temples and houses on the mainland, but he knew he couldn't cross the river.

The next day, he saw a red deer which he knew could swim across the river. He also realized that he had lost all his money after his boat broke. He saw fishermen and shouted for help from the beach like a madman, but eventually they just sat and laughed. He went to tell him in broken English that the river would be shallow when the tide came up. He felt surprised and embarrassed when he found out that he could easily jump across the river when the tide came up.

0.text: The scene opens in Caesar's house. It is a stormy night and Calphurnia has dreamed of Caesar's murder. She asks a servant to instruct an augurer to interpret the signs, and she implores Caesar on her knees to stay at home. The servant returns, advising that Caesar should stay at home, and eventually he agrees, and he will advise Antony to tell the Senators that he is sick. Decius Brutus enters and he gives his interpretation to the omen. The vision concerned Romans dipping their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius says that Calphurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood reviving Rome and the Romans are smiling because they are renewed. Decius goes on to suggest that the Senate will ridicule Caesar for being governed by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitol. Caesar arrives and he welcomes Antony who is suffering the effects of partying the previous night.

2.text: I'd like to present a scene that took place at Julia Caesar's house. That night was a rainy evening, and Calpurnia had a dream that Caesar was murdered. She then instructed her servants to summon an Augurer to come and give their opinion, and she also turned to Caesar, who was at home, and asked him to stay there. The servants returned and advised Caesar to stay at home, and eventually he agreed and told Antony to tell the Senate that he would not be coming. Brutus and Cassius arrived and gave their opinions regarding the path (which could refer to the path to assassinate him). The vision was related to the Romans who were stepping into the blood flowing out from Caesar's symbol. Cassius spoke that Calpurnia's dream was a sign of Caesar's blood that would bring joy to Rome and the Romans because they would be restored. Cassius also said that the Senate would be driven mad by Caesar because he was controlled by his wife's dream. Caesar changed his mind and went to the Senate. Caesar arrived and smiled at Antony, who was ill because he had attended a party the night before.

ฉันพยายามสร้างบรรยากาศวันเกิดคลีโอพัตรา โดยมีฝนและลม และเพื่อนของคลีโอพัตรากำลังวางแผนจะฆ่าออกเทเซีย  กายุสส่งทหารไปจับแอนโทนีเพื่อป้องกันเขาจากหนี แต่ในที่สุดก็ปล่อยเขาและบอกวุฒิสภาว่า กายุสไม่ควรกลับมา

บรูตัสและคาซิอุสมาถึงและวางแผน (อาจจะฆ่ากายุส) ในขณะที่กำลังขี่ม้า แต่ความคิดของพวกเขากำหนดโดยเลือดที่ไหลออกมาจากบาดแผลของกายุส ซึ่งส่วนใหญ่เป็นขนาดใหญ่  เขารู้ว่าฝนของคลีโอพัตราเป็นรหัส และเลือดของเขาต้องกลายเป็นภาษาละติน  คาซิอุสมีความเข้าใจว่าไม่ว่าเขาจะเป็นเจ้าชายหรือไม่ ไม่สำคัญเพราะเขายังคงอยู่ในฝันของคลีโอพัตรา แต่ใจของเขายังคงอยู่กับราชบัลลังก์  กายุสเตือนเขาว่าเขาจะล้มเหลวและเขากำลังเล่นกับแอนโทนี แต่แอนโทนีเชื่อว่าเขาจะถูกจับเพราะเขาได้รับเชิญไปงานปาร์ตี้

0.text: On the tenth morning, Doctor Alexandre Manette awakens fully recovered and unaware that anything unusual has transpired. Mr. Lorry tactfully conveys to the Doctor what has happened and asks what caused the relapse and how it can be prevented. The Doctor explains that he expected the relapse, which was caused by the revival of certain memories. He believes that the worst is over and doubts that another relapse could occur; if one did, it would most likely result from an intense experience that revived those same memories. Mr. Lorry also questions the wisdom of keeping the shoemaking bench and materials, pointing out that their presence reminds the Doctor of the past that has caused him so much pain. Uneasily agreeing, Doctor Manette requests that Mr. Lorry dispose of the bench and tools without him. Therefore, Mr. Lorry and Miss Pross bury the tools and burn the shoemaking bench after the Doctor leaves to join Lucie and Darnay on their trip.

2.text: On the tenth day, Morning, researcher Alexander Manette seemed to be improving and was unsure about what was happening abnormally. Miss Pross explained to the researcher and asked what was causing him to improve and how to prevent it from happening again. The researcher explained that he had been restored, which occurred because some information he had received had been restored to him. He thought that the disaster had already occurred and was not confident that there would be another restoration if it happened again. If it happened again, it would be because of the intense experience that had been restored to his memory. Miss Pross also asked about the appropriateness of storing the table and shoe-making tools and materials, saying that this made the researcher think of the past that made him suffer. The researcher hesitated and asked Miss Pross to destroy the table and shoe-making tools without telling him. Miss Pross and the two of them buried the shoe-making tools and burned the shoe-making table after the researcher left to join Lucy and Darney.
