On the tenth day, Dr. Aster still felt scared and uncertain. He listened to Dr. Pro's explanation and asked what had been improved and how to prevent this event from happening again. Dr. Pro explained that it was improved because some data had been sent back. He thought that this event had already happened and understood that it would happen again if the data didn't follow through. If it happened again, it was because a very intense event had been sent back into his memory.

Dr. Pro also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him to regret bringing back his past memories. Dr. Pro still made a decision and told Dr. Pro to destroy the equipment and workbench without telling Dr. Aster beforehand. Dr. Pro and both of them buried the equipment and burned the workbench after Dr. Pro left with his son and Dory.

16.text:
On the tenth day, Commander Arthur was still feeling scared and uncertain. He listened to Commander Pro explain the situation and asked what improvements had been made and how to prevent this from happening again. Commander Pro explained that improvements had been made because data had been sent back. He thought that this event had already occurred, and he understood that this event would happen again if the data was inconsistent. If it happened again, it would be because a high-intensity event had been sent back to his memory.

Commander Pro also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him to regret bringing back memories of the past. Commander Pro had already made a decision and told Commander Pro to destroy the equipment and workbench without telling Commander Arthur. Commander Pro and both men buried the equipment and burned the workbench after Commander Pro left with his son and Dory.

20.text:
On the tenth day, Arthur was still scared and uncertain. He listened as Arthur explained the situation and asked what had been improved and how to solve this problem. Arthur explained that it had been improved because the information had been sent back in. He thought that this event had already occurred and understood that this event would occur again if the information was incorrect. If it occurred again, it was because his creative idea had sent it back into his memory.

Arthur also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him to regret mentioning memories of the past at this time. Arthur decided and told him to destroy the equipment and worktable without telling Arthur. Arthur and the two of them buried the equipment and burned the worktable after Arthur left with his son and Dory.

25.text:
On the tenth day, Arthur was still afraid and unsure. He listened to an explanation of his situation and asked what had been improved and what problems had been solved. Arthur explained that it had been improved because the information had been returned to him. He thought that this event had already occurred and understood that it would happen again if the information was incorrect. If it happened again, it was because his creative thoughts had been returned to his memory.

Arthur also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him not to agree with mentioning memories of the past at this time. Arthur made a decision and told him not to tell Arthur to destroy equipment and the workbench without telling him. Arthur and the other two people buried the equipment and burned the workbench after Arthur left with his son and Dory.

30.text:
On the tenth day, Arthur was still afraid and uncertain. He listened to the explanation of his situation and asked what had been improved and what problems had been solved. Arthur said that he had improved because he had received feedback. He thought that this event had already occurred and understood that it would happen again if the information was incorrect. If it happened again, it would be due to his creative thinking that was sent back to his memory.

Arthur also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for making shoes and told him that he should not accept that he had to talk about memories of the past at this time. Arthur made a decision and told him that he should not tell Arthur to destroy the equipment and the worktable without telling him first. After Arthur left with his son and Dory, Arthur and the two others buried the equipment and burned the worktable.

40.text:
On the tenth day, Arthur still felt scared and uncertain. He received information about his situation and was asked what had improved and what problems had been solved. Arthur said he could improve because he felt it was just a thought in his head. He thought the event had already happened and he knew it would happen again. If the information was incorrect and it happened again, it was because his creative thoughts were sent back to his memories.

Arthur also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him not to mention that he should talk about his past memories at this time. Arthur was now calm and told him not to tell Arthur that he should destroy the equipment and the workbench without knowing what was inside. After Arthur left with his son and Dorie, Arthur and the others took the tools and burned the workbench.

50.text:
On the 10th, Arthur still felt scared and uncertain. He received information about his situation and was asked what had been improved and what problems had been solved. Arthur said he could improve because he believed it was just a thought in his head. He thought the event had already occurred and he knew it would happen again. If the information was incorrect and it happened again, it was because his creative thinking was sent back to his memory.

Arthur also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him not to mention Arthur's memories of the past at the moment. Arthur returned to a calm state and told him not to tell Arthur to destroy the equipment and the workbench without knowing what it was used for. Arthur left with his son and Dory, and Arthur and others stole tools and burned the workbench.

65.text:
On the 10th, Martin was still afraid and unsure. He received information about his situation and was asked what had been improved and what problems had been solved. Martin said he could improve because he thought it was just a thought in his head. He thought the event had already happened, and he knew it would happen again. If the information was incorrect, and again, that was just his creative thought that he thought was his memory.

Martin also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him not to mention Martin's memory at that time. Martin returned to normal and told him not to mention Martin who destroyed the equipment and the worktable without knowing what it was for. Martin left together with his son and Dorey, and Martin and others were responsible for taking care of the tools and burning the worktable.

80.text:
At that time, Martin was still feeling scared and uncertain. He was given information about his situation and was asked what had been improved and what problems had been solved. Martin said that he could improve because he thought it was just a thought in his head. He thought the event had already occurred and he knew it would happen again. If the information was incorrect, it would be a drill, which he thought was his memory.

Martin also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him not to mention Martin's memory at that time. Martin returned to his normal state and told him not to mention the destruction of the equipment and the worktable without knowing what it was used for. Martin and his son, as well as Dory, left together, and Martin and others were responsible for taking care of the tools and burning the worktable.

100.text:
At the same time, Martin thought about his fear and uncertainty. He received information about his situation and asked what had been improved and what problems had been solved. Martin said he could improve because he thought it was a thought in his head. He thought that event had already occurred and he knew it would happen again. If that information was incorrect, it would be a rehearsal session, which he thought was his memory.

Martin also asked about the appropriateness of storing equipment and materials for shoe production and told him not to mention Martin's memory at that time. Martin returned to normal and told him not to mention the destruction of equipment and the workbench without knowing how to use them. Martin's son and Dorie were left behind. Martin and others were sent to take care of the tools and burn the workbench.

0.text: The Underground Man wishes that his constant state of inaction were simply because of laziness. That sure would make things easier. And at least then, he says, he could respect himself. Also, at least he would have certainty. If someone asked what he was, the answer would be clear: a lazy person! For example: the Underground Man once knew a guy who was a connoisseur of Lafitte . That was pretty much the guy's only defining feature, but at least he had a defining feature. So he died a happy man. The point is that the Underground Man has no such vocation. If he could pick something to be, he'd pick...mmm...a glutton . A glutton who can appreciate 'everything sublime and beautiful.' The more he thinks about it, the more he realizes that should have been what his life was about: appreciating the sublime and beautiful. He realizes that such a life would probably have meant a lot of crying. Any time someone did anything beautiful or sublime, he would have wept in awe. He also would have gotten fat and red in the nose.

2.text:
The Underdog Man wants to be considered as a person who never does anything because of his weakness. If that's the case, his life will be easier. He says he will definitely respect himself, be confident, and let others ask what he is, and the answer will be clear: weak! 

For example, the Underdog Man knows someone who is very sensitive, like Lafitte. That's the only characteristic he has, but he has it to the fullest, so he died with a smile on his face.

But the Underdog Man doesn't have this characteristic. If he could choose to be something, he would choose...oh...a glutton. A glutton who can admire 'great and beautiful' things as much as he wants. He doesn't know why, but he feels that his life should have this characteristic: admiring great and beautiful things. He feels that a life like that means crying a lot every time someone else does something great or beautiful. He will cry out of respect. He will still eat a lot and be red.

4.text:
This man wants others to see that he's not doing anything because he's weak. If that's the case, his life will be easier. He says he'll respect himself, be confident, and let others ask what he is. The answer will be clear: weak!

For example, a weak acquaintance of mine has a gentle nature like a left-handed person. That's the only trait he has, but he has everything, so he died with a smile on his face.

But this kind of weak person doesn't have this trait. If he could choose what to be, he would choose...hmm...a glutton, a glutton who can admire 'great and beautiful' the most. He doesn't know why, but he feels that his life should have this trait: admiring greatly and beautifully. He feels that a good life is crying every time someone else does something great or beautiful. He cries out of respect. He still eats a lot and turns red.

6.text:
He wants others to see that he can't do anything because he is weak. If that's the case, his life will be easier. He says he admires himself, is confident, and wants others to ask what he is. The answer is clear: weak!

For example, a friend of mine who doesn't know me well has a characteristic of being a laid-back person like a left-handed person. That's the only characteristic he has, but he has many other things. So, he died with a smile on his face.

But people like this don't have this characteristic. If he wants to choose, he will choose...hmm...a person who eats a lot. A person who eats a lot can admire, 'Beautiful and beautiful.' 0.text: Coriolanus shows up at the marketplace ready to deliver the big apology. The plebeians, along with Sicinius and Brutus, are waiting for him. First, Menenius reminds everyone that Coriolanus is a big war hero with the scars to prove it. The tribunes decide it's time to pounce and waste no time provoking Coriolanus. Sicinius officially accuses him of acting like a big old tyrant and a traitor, which--big shock--sends Coriolanus into yet another rage. Coriolanus proceeds to insult the tribunes and plebeians, daring them to punish him with exile, death, or torture. Meanwhile, his senator buddies can only stand by and watch this train wreck unfold. Finally, the tribunes declare that Coriolanus is banned from Rome 4EVA. Coriolanus is all 'Oh yeah? I don't think so. You're not banishing me. I'm banishing you!'

2.text: Coriolanus arrived at the market ready to apologize in full. The citizens, along with Sicinius and Brutus, were waiting for him. Menenius, the first advisor, warned everyone to remember that Coriolanus was a renowned warrior with many scars. Both advisors decided that it was time to apprehend Coriolanus and not waste time trying to persuade him. Sicinius was the first to accuse Coriolanus of being a thief and a traitor to the state, which was unbelievable, making Coriolanus angry once again. Coriolanus spoke coarsely to the advisors and the citizens, and bravely declared that they should punish him properly by exile, execution, or harshly. Meanwhile, his fellow members of the association there could only sit and watch the situation unfolding. Finally, the advisors announced that Coriolanus was forever banished from Rome. Coriolanus spoke, 'Oh, indeed! I didn't think it would happen. You can't exile me! I am the one who will exile you!'

0.text: The Wood-Sawyer Lucie is unsure for one year and three months whether her husband has been alive or dead. She establishes a routine in their new home, and she keeps herself hopeful by setting aside a chair or books for her husband and otherwise behaving as if he lived there, too. Her father informs her that there is a place that she can stand on the sidewalk during certain hours which is overlooked by a window in the prison which her husband may sometimes look out. Lucie faithfully walks back and forth on that sidewalk for two hours each day. Jacques Four has now become a wood-sawyer and has a shack to cut wood near where Lucie walks. He notices that she is there every day, and he mocks her for knowing someone in the prison, pretending to guillotine the whole family with his saw. During December, a crowd of five hundred including Jacques Four and the Vengeance descend on Lucie while she is walking near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her that they will not harm her. Madame Defarge walks by and salutes them. Charles is summoned to appear in court the next day

2.text: Lucy, the wife of the logger, is not sure if her husband is alive or dead for one year and three months. She has organized her daily life in the new house and kept hope alive by preparing chairs or books for her husband and behaving as if he were still there. Her father informed her that there is a place where she can stand on the street at the designated time, which has a view of the prison window that her husband might see her. Lucy walked along that street for two hours a day with confidence. A man named Jacks Ford became a logger and had a small back near the logging area that Lucy passed through. He saw her every day and liked to joke with her because he knew people in the prison and pretended to stockpile the entire family with his pocket knife. In December, a crowd of 500 people, including Jacks Ford and Vengeance, surrounded Lucy as she walked near the prison. She was frightened, but her father told her not to be afraid of being harmed. Madame Defarge passed by and respected them. Charles was summoned to appear in court the next day.

0.text: In the year 1640, the Hall of the Hotel de Bourgogne--a large, crowded Parisian theater--buzzes with activity in the minutes before a performance of the play La Clorise. People mill about and converse, divided according to their social class. A citizen guides his son through the room, impressing upon him the intellectual magnitude of the performance. A thief moves through the crowd, stealing handkerchiefs and purses. A group of pages runs about firing peashooters at one another. Two elegant marquises, with swords strapped to their waists, tread through the crowd, aloof and condescending. The lamps are lit, and the crowd cheers, knowing the performance will commence soon

2.text: In April 1640, the Théâtre du Marais - a large and bustling theatre in Paris - was abuzz with energy just moments before the performance of 'La Clorise'. People milled about, talking incessantly, divided by social class. One politician led his son through the hall, cautioning him to appreciate the intellectual significance of the performance. A would-be assassin walked through the crowd, snatching a handkerchief and a purse. A group of students, friends, walked by, firing cap guns at each other. Two beautiful young men, with daggers hanging from their waists, strode through the crowd with haughty disdain. The lights in the hall were lit, and the crowd was electrified, sensing that the performance was about to begin.

4.text: In April 1760 at the Théâtre du Marais in Paris, a brief commotion erupted before the performance of 'La Clorise.' An assassin attempted to blend in with the crowd, stealing a handkerchief and a purse. A group of young people walked by, firing their pistols at each other. Two actors, each with a sword at their waist, walked through the crowd, self-absorbed. The people in the lobby were excited, and those in this corner felt that the performance would begin soon.

Politicians escorted their sons through the foyer, warning them of the importance of this intellectual performance. Assassins attempted to blend in with the crowd by stealing towels and wallets. A group of young people walked through, ignoring the scene, and fired guns back and forth without pause. Each actor carried a stick in their belt as they walked through the crowd with determination. Those in the foyer were excited, and those in the surrounding area felt that the performance was about to begin quickly.

20.text:
ในเดือนเมษายน 1788 มีการบานปลายเกิดขึ้นระหว่างการแสดง 'La Clorise' ที่ Théâtre du Marais ในปารีส ก่อนการแสดง ผู้คนจากหลายสาขาชีวิตต่างๆ ยังคงเข้าและออกจากห้องอาหาร นักการเมืองนำเด็กๆ เข้าไปในห้องอาหาร โดยเตือนพวกเขาไม่ให้เข้าใจความหมายทางจิตวิญญาณของการแสดง คนร้ายพยายามผสมกับชุมชนเพื่อขโมยกระเป๋าของผู้เดินทาง กลุ่มเด็กๆ เดินผ่านไปโดยไม่รู้ตัวและยิงปืนอย่างต่อเนื่องเข้าไปในชุมชน แต่ละนักแสดงมีเทียนและโคมไฟอยู่บนหัวขณะที่เดินผ่านชุมชนด้วยความมุ่งมั่น ผู้คนในห้องอาหารมีความตื่นเต้น และผู้ที่อยู่ใกล้ๆ รู้สึกว่าการแสดงจะเริ่มขึ้นเร็วๆ นี้

0.text: The setting shifts to the outside battlements of the castle at Elsinore. As earlier planned, Hamlet arrives with Horatio and Marcellus, just before midnight in order to watch for the Ghost. While they are speaking to one another, a flourish of trumpets and canon fire is heard in the distance. Hamlet explains in disgust that this is a sign that the new King, his uncle and stepfather, is engaged in his customary drunken revelry. Suddenly the ghost appears. Hamlet addresses the apparition as 'King, father; royal Dane' and implores it to reveal the reason for its nocturnal wanderings. The ghost simply beckons Hamlet to follow it to another place. Horatio and Marcellus beg Hamlet not to obey the ghost, fearing it would be dangerous and could even lead to his death; but Hamlet ignores his friends' warnings, breaks away from them when they try to physically restrain him, and follows the Ghost. Horatio and Marcellus are convinced that 'something is rotten in the state of Denmark' and decide to follow Hamlet.

2.text: Around midnight, before the bell was rung, Hamlet and Marcellus had gone to Elsinore's castle wall as per the original plan. There, they met Horatio to watch the royal spirits. While they were there, they heard the sound of cannons and flutes from far away. Hamlet explained in an unsatisfied tone that this was a sign that the new king was drunk and his uncle and husband of his father. When the spirits appeared, Hamlet called out, 'Spirits of my father and King of Denmark,' and asked why the spirits appeared at midnight. However, the spirits only told Hamlet to follow them to another place. Horatio and Marcellus both asked Hamlet not to follow the spirits because they thought it would be unsafe and might lead to Hamlet's death. But Hamlet didn't listen to his friends' warnings and followed the spirits. Horatio and Marcellus believed that 'there is something rotten in the state of Denmark' and decided to follow Hamlet.

0.text: It is summer at Longbourn; Lydia has gone to Brighton, and Mrs. Bennet and Kitty constantly complain of boredom. Mr. Bennett, as always, stays aloof and uninvolved. Elizabeth, remembering the contents of Darcys letter, is more bothered by her parents behavior than ever. She realizes they are totally mismatched and decides she will not marry until she finds someone with whom she can have a proper and supportive relationship. Unlike the bored Kitty and her mother, Elizabeth is eagerly awaiting her trip with the Gardiners. As she dreams about the northern tour, she receives a letter explaining that the trip has to be shortened to only Derbyshire. She is momentarily disappointed, for she has been looking forward to seeing the lake. The Gardiners take Elizabeth to Lambton, where Mrs. Gardiner once resided. Pemberley, Darcys residence, is situated about five miles away. Elizabeth is persuaded by her aunt and uncle to visit Pemberley, since the family is away.

0.text: In order to best describe Typee life, the narrator profiles a typical day. Usually, they wake late, after the sun is up. Then they rise and bathe in a nearby refreshing stream. A light breakfast is enjoyed and then pipes are smoked. After breakfast, people tend to whatever they like. Tinor inspects her cloth and food supplies; Marheyo works on his hut; the girls adorn their hair and skin with oils. The narrator usually wanders with Kory-Kory or else sits inside. Then they enjoy a midday nap. Usually in the afternoon, the narrator goes to the Ti, where Mehevi and the other chiefs gather. Since women are not allowed in the Ti, it resembles a happy bachelor pad where the best food can be found and where the men sit around smoking and talking. After night falls, a light evening meal of 'poee-poee,' cooked breadfruit, is eaten. Native girls often dance around their huts under the moonlight. Everyone then sleeps. In general, life with the Typees resembles a continual gentle slumber, with activities in between

16.text: เอ็ดมันด์เดินทางไปที่ปราสาทของเอิร์ลแห่งกลอสเตอร์ โดยหวังว่าจะเจรจาเพิ่มเติมและขอความช่วยเหลือจากพระมหากษัตริย์ในการยกเลิกกฎหมายที่ขัดขวางความหวังของเขา เขาเริ่มวางแผนการกำจัดเอ็ดการ์ และเมื่อเอิร์ลมาถึง เขาก็นำเอกสารปลอมมาแสดงให้พ่อของเขาเห็นว่าเอกสารปลอมนั้นมาจากเอ็ดการ์ เอกสารปลอมนั้นระบุว่าเอ็ดมันด์และเอ็ดการ์จะร่วมมือกันทำให้พ่อของเอ็ดมันด์รู้สึกไม่สบายใจและฆ่าเอิร์ล แบ่งทรัพย์สินของเอิร์ล นักบวชแห่งกลอสเตอร์ถูกหลอกได้ง่ายเพราะเขาได้ยินเรื่องราวเกี่ยวกับปราสาทของพระมหากษัตริย์หลังจากเอิร์ลแห่งกลอสเตอร์ออกไป เอดมันด์นำเสนอตนเองว่าเป็นคนสร้างความภาคภูมิใจให้กับพ่อของเขา และเมื่อเอ็ดการ์มาถึง เขาก็บอกให้เอ็ดการ์ไปฆ่าพ่อของตัวเองเพื่อปกป้องตัวเอง ตามคำแนะนำของอาร์ชบิชอป เอดมันด์สามารถเข้าใจอารมณ์ของเอ็ดการ์ได้ และเอ็ดการ์เชื่อเขา

0.text: The gathering in the forest is joined by Ivanhoe and Gurth, and they all gather for a feast. Ivanhoe tells Richard that his kingdom is in disarray and he should act quickly to reclaim it. Richard replies that he needs to wait until he is sure that the various forces he is depending on are marshaled and ready. Robin Hood also fears that Richard should not stay in the forest too long. He sets up a ruse whereby it appears they are under attack by Normans. This brings the banquet to a sudden end. Then Robin confesses the ruse to Richard, and Richard realizes that it is indeed time for him to move on. He sets off with Ivanhoe, Gurth and Wamba for Athelstane's castle, which is in mourning for its lost leader

2.text: Ewanho and Gort joined a midday meal in the forest and everyone sat down to eat. Ewanho told Raginald that his territory was in turmoil and he should act quickly to reclaim it. Raginald replied that he had to wait until he was certain that he was not relying on the pressure of various problems and was ready to move. Robbin Hood feared that Raginald should not stay in the forest too long, so he devised a plan to make it seem as though they were being attacked by the Normans, which immediately brought the celebration to a halt. Then, Robbin Hood told Raginald his plan and Raginald understood that he should continue his journey. He traveled on with Ewanho, Gort, and Wamba to the castle of Talsan, where they were being mocked for the loss of their leader.

4.text: Evron and Gort sat down to eat lunch in the forest, and everyone sat down to eat. Evron told Reginald that his region was in chaos and he should act quickly to restore the region. Reginald replied that he should wait until he was certain that he was not relying on the pressure of several problems and was ready to move. Robin Hood was worried that Reginald should not stay in the forest too long, so he made a plan as if they were being attacked by the Normans, which immediately put the celebration to a halt. Then Robin Hood told Reginald his plan. Reginald understood that he should continue his journey. He journeyed on with Evron, Gort, and Will Scarlett to Tuck's Castle, where they were mocked for the loss of their leader.

6.text: Everword and Cort sat down for lunch in the forest, and everyone ate together. Everword told Reginald that his region was in turmoil and that he should act quickly to help his region. Reginald replied that he should wait until he was certain that he was not relying on the pressure of various problems and was ready to move. Robin Hood was worried that Reginald should not stay in the forest for too long, so he made a plan as if they were being attacked by the Normans, which immediately halted the celebration. Then, Robin Hood told Reginald his plan. Reginald understood that he should continue with his trip. He traveled on with Everword, Cort, and Will Scarlett to Tuck's Castle, where they were mocked because of their loss of leader.

Reginald replied that he should wait until he was certain that he was not relying on the pressure of various problems and was ready to move. Robin Hood was concerned that Reginald should not stay in the woods too long, so he planned as if they were attacked by the Normans, which immediately halted the celebration. He traveled on with Everwood, Cort, and Will Scarlett to Tickhill Castle, where they were mocked for the loss of their leader.

10.text: Everwood and Court had a midday meal in the woods, and everyone ate together. Everwood told Reginald that his region was in a chaotic situation and he should act quickly to help his region. Reginald replied that he should wait until he was certain that he wasn't being pressured by multiple problems and was ready to move. Robin Hood worried that Reginald shouldn't stay in the woods for too long, so he planned as if they were being attacked by the Normans, which would immediately end the celebration. Then, Robin Hood told Reginald his plan. Reginald understood that he should continue his journey. He traveled with Everwood, Court, and Will Scarlett from Tuckhill Castle, where they were mocked for the loss of their leader.

13.text: On a midday holiday, the group ate together in the Everwood forest. Everwood told Reginald that his region was in a chaotic situation and that he should act quickly to help his region. Reginald replied that he should wait until he was certain that he was not under pressure from many problems and was ready to move. Robin Hood worried that Reginald should not stay in the forest for long. So, he planned as if they were being attacked by the Normans, which would immediately stop the celebration. Then, Robin Hood told his plan to Reginald. Reginald understood that he should continue his journey. He traveled with Everwood, Court, and Will Scarlett from the Tuck Hill castle, where they were teased over their loss of their leader.

16.text:
When the midday break came, the group received food together in the Everwood forest. Everwood told Reginald that his region was in a state of abnormality, and they should act quickly to help his region. Reginald said they should wait until he was sure they wouldn't be pressured by many problems and were ready to move. 

Robin Hood was worried that Reginald shouldn't stay in the forest for too long, so he planned as if they were attacked by the Normans, which would stop the celebration quickly. Then Robin Hood told his plan to Reginald. 

Reginald understood that he should act, so he traveled together with Everwood, Court, and Will Scarlett from the Tuckenhall Castle. There, they were mocked about their losses.

20.text:
When daybreak arrived, a group of people shared food in the Everwood forest. Everwood told Reginald that his region was in an abnormal situation and needed to be resolved as soon as possible to help his region. Reginald said they should wait until he was certain they were not under pressure from numerous problems and were ready to move.

Donald Hood was surprised that Reginald should not have stayed in the forest for so long, so he planned as if they were being attacked by the Normans, which would end the celebration quickly. Then Donald Hood told Reginald about his plan.

Reginald understood that he should act, so he traveled with Everwood, Cort, and Will Scarlet from the Tuckenhall Castle. There, they were mocked about their loss.

25.text:
In the early morning, when the time was close to dawn, the group sat waiting for food in the Everwood forest. Everwood told Reginald that his region was facing an abnormal situation and needed to be resolved quickly to help his region. Reginald said that they should wait until he was certain that they were not under pressure from multiple problems and were ready to move.

Dowdok was upset that Reginald had stayed in the forest for so long, so he planned for Norway to attack to quickly end the celebration. Then, Dowdok told Reginald his plan.

Reginald knew he had to act, so he traveled with Everwood, Cort, and Will Scarlet from Tuckenholt Castle to there. They were mocked about their losses.

30.text:
In the morning, when the sun was about to set over the new land, a group of people were waiting for food in the town of Everwood. Everwood told Reginald that his region was in an abnormal situation and needed to be fixed as soon as possible to help his region. Reginald said that they should wait until he was sure that they were not being pressured by multiple problems and were ready to move.

Daveth was unhappy that Reginald had been in the woods for a long time, so he planned for Nafuriel to lead an attack to quickly end the celebration. Then, Daveth told Reginald about his plan.

Reginald understood that he had to do something, so he traveled with Everwood, Cort, and Will, Scarlet from the Clanholme Castle, to there. They were mocked about their losses.

40.text:
Today in the morning, when the sun was setting in the area they had passed through earlier, the tour group waiting for food at Everwood was informed by Everwood that there was a problem in that area and they had to fix it soon to help the area. Regan told them not to travel further than he could be sure they wouldn't get hurt from the problem and be ready to travel again.

David was not happy that Regan had gone into the woods a lot, so he planned for Nafaret to be the leader of the response team. Then, David told Regan about his plan.

0.text: Cinna the poet is on his way to attend Caesar's funeral when he is accosted by a group of riotous citizens who demand to know who he is and where he is going. He tells them that his name is Cinna and his destination is Caesar's funeral. They mistake him, however, for the conspirator Cinna and move to assault him. He pleads that he is Cinna the poet and not Cinna the conspirator, but they reply that they will kill him anyway because of 'his bad verses.' With Cinna captive, the crowd exits, declaring their intent to burn the houses belonging to Brutus, Cassius, Decius, Casca, and Caius Ligarius.

2.text: Sinna, the poet, traveled to attend the funeral of Julius Caesar. He protested and said that he was Sinna the poet, not the one who killed, but they argued that they would still kill him because 'his poetry was bad.' When Sinna was apprehended, the mob dispersed and announced that they would burn the houses of Brutus, Cassius, Decidius, Gaius, and Caesar.
